Manx: Arrane ayns Gaelg
English: A Song in Manx
Diplomatic: Arrane ayns Galg

Manx: Feer foddey nish voish Mannin veen,
English: Very far now from gentle Mannin,
Diplomatic: Feer foddey nish voish Mannin veen

Manx: My Ellan veg çheu hiar jeh’n cheayn,
English: My little Island on the west side of the sea ,
Diplomatic: My Ellan veg cheu hiar jeh’n cheayn

Manx: Ayns kione heer Nerin wooar ta mee,
English: I’m in the west end of great Ireland ,
Diplomatic: Ayns kione heer Nherin wooar ta mee

Manx: Gyn nane dy gherjaghey my chree.
English: No one to console my heart.
Diplomatic: Gyn nane dy gherjaghey my chree

Manx: Ta’n sleih ayns shoh myr yn cretoor,
English: The people here like the creature,
Diplomatic: Ta’n sleih ayns shoh mor yn cretooar

Manx: Yn Cheeill jeight seose fegooish preachoor,
English: The church shut up without a preacher,
Diplomatic: Yn Keeil jeight seose fegoish preachoor

Manx: Ta’n Saggyrt Claghagh ayns Goleen,
English: The Rector Stoney in Goleen,
Diplomatic: Ta’n saggyrt cloghagh ayns goleen
Notes:
Saggyrt Claghagh; Rev. J.J. Stoney 1840-1900 (Jeeagh er; Rector Stoney ayns ‘A Manx Fisherman’s Poem’). 

Goleen; balley beg faggys da Crookhaven.

Manx: Preacheil da’n çhaglym echey hene.
English: Preaches to his own congregation.
Diplomatic: Preacheeil dan chaglym eck eh hene

Manx: Cha vel aym boayl dy cheau yn traa,
English: I have nowhere to spend the time,
Diplomatic: Cha vel aym boayl dy cheau yn tra

Manx: Agh lhie er boayrd dy chooilley laa,
English: Only lying on-board every day,
Diplomatic: Agh lhie er boyrd dy chooilley laa

Manx: Nish foddey veih my ainjyssee,
English: Now far from my acquaintances,
Diplomatic: Nish foddey veih my ainjessee

Manx: Gyn fakin veg agh Mraane Yernee.
English: Seeing nothing but Irish Women.
Diplomatic: Gyn fakin veg agh Mraane yernee.

Manx: As ooilley croink as creggyn rooisht,
English: And all hills and rocks bare,
Diplomatic: As ooilley croink as creggan roosht

Manx: As Yernee cheoie ta lane jymmoose,
English: And wild Irish that are full of wrath,
Diplomatic: As yernee chaie ta lane jymmoose

Manx: Bare lhiam ve reesht myr va mee keayrt,
English: I’d rather be back as I was once,
Diplomatic: Baare lhiam ve reesht mor va mee cheayrt

Manx: Ayns Mannin veg rouail mygeayrt.
English: In little Mannin, wandering around.
Diplomatic: Ayns mannin veg rouaill mygeayrt

Manx: Er sleityn bwee as gorrym jiarg,
English: On yellow and purple mountians,
Diplomatic: Er sleityn bwee as gorrym jiarg

Manx: Fud conney freoaie er croink dy ard,
English: High up, through heather on hills,
Diplomatic: Fud chonney fraie er croink dy ard

Manx: Raad boallin ayns yn fastyr shooyl,
English: Where I used to walk in the evening,
Diplomatic: Raad bollyn ayns yn fastyr shooyl

Manx: Er Cronk-ny-Arrey as Cronk Veayl.
English: On Cronk-ny-Arrey (Laa) as Cronk Meayl.
Diplomatic: Er cronk ny arrey as cronk vulle

Manx: Dy mennick smooinaghtyn ny-yeih,
English: Often thinking nevertheless,
Diplomatic: Dy mennick smooinnaghtyn ny-yeih

Manx: Er Mannin veg nish foddey veih,
English: About little Mannin now far off,
Diplomatic: Er Mannin veg nish foddey veih

Manx: Raad ta’n sleih ayns fea as shee,
English: Where the people are in calm and peace,
Diplomatic: Raad ta yn sleih ayns fea as shee

Manx: As tannaghtyn ayns aggle Yee.
English: And remain in fear of God.
Diplomatic: As tanniaghtyn ayns aggle Yee

Manx: Ayns shoh cha vel yn doonaght hene,
English: Here, not even the sabbath itself,
Diplomatic: Ayns shoh cha vel yn doonniagh hene

Manx: Freayl ad voish labbragh er y cheayn,
English: Keeps them from working on the sea,
Diplomatic: Freayl ad voish labbragh er y cheayn

Manx: Mraane aegey daunsyn as feer reagh,
English: Young women dancing and very merry,
Diplomatic: Mraane aigey dhaunsyn as feer reagh

Manx: Son cha nel Yernee mennick feagh.
English: For the Irish are not often calm.
Diplomatic: Son cha nel yernee mennick feagh

Manx: Polecheiyt as shynnee shooyl son bee,
English: Polecats and foxes patrolling for food,
Diplomatic: Polechyt as as shynnee shooyl son bee

Manx: Ta mennick rouaill ayns yn oie,
English: Are often wandering in the night,
Diplomatic: Ta mennick rouaill ayns yn oie

Manx: As moddee gounsternee dy keoie,
English: And dogs barking wildly,
Diplomatic: As moddee ghounsternee dy chaie

Manx: Voish sleityn ard er gys yn traie.
English: From high mountains to the shore.
Diplomatic: Voish sleityn ard er gys yn traie

Manx: Ta’n earrish rioeeagh er ve saase,
English: The freezing weather has been a means,
Diplomatic: Ta’n earrish rioyagh er ve saase

Manx: Ayns shoh dy stroie ny blaaghyn gaase,
English: Here to destroy the growing blossoms,
Diplomatic: Ayns shoh dy stroie ny blaggyn gaase

Manx: As ta shen Newman gaccan croie,
English: And it is that of which Newman* harshly complains;
Diplomatic: As ta shen Newman gackan croi

Manx: Dy vel yn rioyn croie er stroie.
English: That hard frosts have laid waste.
Diplomatic: Dy vel yn rioyn crap er stroie

Manx: Agh nish ta’n rio dy slane ersooyl,
English: But now the ice is completely gone,
Diplomatic: Agh nish ta’n rio dy slane ersooyl

Manx: As geay as fliaghey cheet ny chooyl,
English: And wind and rain coming behind it,
Diplomatic: As gheay as fliaghey cheet ny chooyl

Manx: Ta’n thalloo injyl meeley nish,
English: The low land is softening now,
Diplomatic: Ta’n thalloo injyl meeley nish

Manx: Son cha vel monney grian cheet rish,
English: For there isn’t much sun appearing.
Diplomatic: Son cha vel monney ghrain cheet rish

Manx: Foast ta ny ushagyn lesh kiaull,
English: Yet, the birds, with music,
Diplomatic: Foast ta ny ushagyn lesh kiaull

Manx: Jannoo feer taitnysagh yn boayl,
English: Make the place very enjoyable,
Diplomatic: Jannoo feer taitnysagh yn boayl

Manx: Ny magheryn ayns nyn goamrey glass,
English: The fields in their green rainment,
Diplomatic: Ny maghryn ayns nyn goamrey ghlass

Manx: Ga nagh vel monney ghrian ny çhiass.
English: Although there isn’t much sun or heat.
Diplomatic: Gha nagh vel monney ghrain ny chass
